key_points: Democrats gained control of the Senate, achieving a trifecta with the White House and both Congressional chambers.
Vice President Kamala Harris swore in Senators-elect Jon Ossoff, Alex Padilla, and Raphael Warnock, securing the Democratic majority.
Democrats and Republicans each hold 50 seats in the Senate, with VP Harris providing the tie-breaking vote.
Senator Patrick Leahy was elected president pro tempore of the Senate.
Senate Majority Leader Chuck Schumer emphasized a busy agenda centered on President Biden's priorities, including the COVID-19 response.
Schumer contrasts the new Democratic majority’s approach with former Majority Leader Mitch McConnell’s tenure, promising a more proactive Senate.
Mitch McConnell, now Minority Leader, expressed skepticism about a Democratic mandate due to the narrow majority.
Schumer and McConnell discussed a power-sharing arrangement similar to one from 2001, aiming for equal committee representation and fair legislative procedures.
McConnell warned against eliminating the legislative filibuster, which requires 60 votes for most legislation to move forward.
The Senate’s priorities include passing a comprehensive government and ethics reform bill, confirming Mr. Biden’s nominees, and an imminent impeachment trial for former President Trump.
